prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Source selection: VZ Cha is a disk with infrared spectroscopic evidence for a disk wind (Bast et al. 2011), but no nearby companion.
The remainder of our technical justification text is the same for all targets.
Spectral settings: We choose 12CO 2-1 at 230 GHz as our primary line target, with the goal of detecting any low-density extended emission. We additionally request 13CO and C18O, as these denser gas tracers can be used to study and model the velocity field of the protoplanetary disk if the 12CO emission has a significant non-disk component. We choose a high spectral resolution (0.08 km s-1) to fully resolve the velocity structure of the CO emission lines (expected to have widths of order 2-5 km/s), to match our Cycle 0 data, and because the line central velocities are well-constrained (to within ~5 km/s, compared to the 152 km/s bandwidth). We choose a wide (1875 MHz) band as our 4th baseband to obtain a continuum observation, which is useful for constraining disk models.
The combined information gleaned from the three isotopologues and continuum is extremely useful for determining the mass and velocity of any extended structure and the underlying disk. Therefore, we believe that the high data rate required by this setup is justified.
Sensitivity: Our goals are to detect any extended 12CO emission, and to be able to characterize the velocity field of this emission if it exists. The second goal also requires high sensitivity observations of 13CO, as this is used to trace the disk velocity field. The observed extended emission around AS 205 N has peak fluxes near 0.5 Jy/beam, and so we require at least a nominal sensitivity of 0.05 Jy/beam to obtain a SNR per channel of 10 on any extended emission. Because we also want to study 13CO, we request a slightly higher sensitivity for FX Tau, which has a factor of ~10 less continuum flux than AS 205 N, suggesting it will also have significantly lower CO flux. We therefore request a sensitivity of 0.02 Jy /beam for FX Tau.
Spatial resolution: The high spatial resolution (~0.6") of the Cycle 0 extended configuration was crucial for resolving the sub-arcsecond structures observed around AS 205 N. For these observations, we request a slightly higher resolution (0.3") in order to obtain a few resolution elements across the protoplanetary disks, expected to be of order (0.5-1)" in size. Obtaining several resolution elements across the disk will allow us to determine whether the CO velocity field in the disk is different from Keplerian (as is hinted at in the first moment map shown in Figure 1).
We also request ACA observations for our targets to determine whether they have corresponding molecular outflows, with typical sizes of ~5-15" (e.g. Arce & Sargent 2006).

Source selection: DR Tau is a disk with infrared spectroscopic evidence for a disk wind (Bast et al. 2011, Pontoppidan et al. 2011), but no nearby companion.
The remainder of our technical justification text is the same for all targets.
Spectral settings: We choose 12CO 2-1 at 230 GHz as our primary line target, with the goal of detecting any low-density extended emission. We additionally request 13CO and C18O, as these denser gas tracers can be used to study and model the velocity field of the protoplanetary disk if the 12CO emission has a significant non-disk component. We choose a high spectral resolution (0.08 km s-1) to fully resolve the velocity structure of the CO emission lines (expected to have widths of order 2-5 km/s), to match our Cycle 0 data, and because the line central velocities are well-constrained (to within ~5 km/s, compared to the 152 km/s bandwidth). We choose a wide (1875 MHz) band as our 4th baseband to obtain a continuum observation, which is useful for constraining disk models.
The combined information gleaned from the three isotopologues and continuum is extremely useful for determining the mass and velocity of any extended structure and the underlying disk. Therefore, we believe that the high data rate required by this setup is justified.
Sensitivity: Our goals are to detect any extended 12CO emission, and to be able to characterize the velocity field of this emission if it exists. The second goal also requires high sensitivity observations of 13CO, as this is used to trace the disk velocity field. The observed extended emission around AS 205 N has peak fluxes near 0.5 Jy/beam, and so we require at least a nominal sensitivity of 0.05 Jy/beam to obtain a SNR per channel of 10 on any extended emission. Because we also want to study 13CO, we request a slightly higher sensitivity for FX Tau, which has a factor of ~10 less continuum flux than AS 205 N, suggesting it will also have significantly lower CO flux. We therefore request a sensitivity of 0.02 Jy /beam for FX Tau.
Spatial resolution: The high spatial resolution (~0.6") of the Cycle 0 extended configuration was crucial for resolving the sub-arcsecond structures observed around AS 205 N. For these observations, we request a slightly higher resolution (0.3") in order to obtain a few resolution elements across the protoplanetary disks, expected to be of order (0.5-1)" in size. Obtaining several resolution elements across the disk will allow us to determine whether the CO velocity field in the disk is different from Keplerian (as is hinted at in the first moment map shown in Figure 1).
We also request ACA observations for our targets to determine whether they have corresponding molecular outflows, with typical sizes of ~5-15" (e.g. Arce & Sargent 2006).

Source selection: FX Tau is a binary system with a projected separation of 0.89" and a mass ratio of 0.47 (Harris et al. 2012), similar to the projected separation (1.3") and mass ratio (~0.6) for AS 205. The large difference in flux between the primary and secondary disks in this system (Harris et al.) also suggests that there is significant gravitational interaction between the two.
The remainder of our technical justification text is the same for all targets.
Spectral settings: We choose 12CO 2-1 at 230 GHz as our primary line target, with the goal of detecting any low-density extended emission. We additionally request 13CO and C18O, as these denser gas tracers can be used to study and model the velocity field of the protoplanetary disk if the 12CO emission has a significant non-disk component. We choose a high spectral resolution (0.08 km s-1) to fully resolve the velocity structure of the CO emission lines (expected to have widths of order 2-5 km/s), to match our Cycle 0 data, and because the line central velocities are well-constrained (to within ~5 km/s, compared to the 152 km/s bandwidth). We choose a wide (1875 MHz) band as our 4th baseband to obtain a continuum observation, which is useful for constraining disk models.
The combined information gleaned from the three isotopologues and continuum is extremely useful for determining the mass and velocity of any extended structure and the underlying disk. Therefore, we believe that the high data rate required by this setup is justified.
Sensitivity: Our goals are to detect any extended 12CO emission, and to be able to characterize the velocity field of this emission if it exists. The second goal also requires high sensitivity observations of 13CO, as this is used to trace the disk velocity field. The observed extended emission around AS 205 N has peak fluxes near 0.5 Jy/beam, and so we require at least a nominal sensitivity of 0.05 Jy/beam to obtain a SNR per channel of 10 on any extended emission. Because we also want to study 13CO, we request a slightly higher sensitivity for FX Tau, which has a factor of ~10 less continuum flux than AS 205 N, suggesting it will also have significantly lower CO flux. We therefore request a sensitivity of 0.02 Jy /beam for FX Tau.
Spatial resolution: The high spatial resolution (~0.6") of the Cycle 0 extended configuration was crucial for resolving the sub-arcsecond structures observed around AS 205 N. For these observations, we request a slightly higher resolution (0.3") in order to obtain a few resolution elements across the protoplanetary disks, expected to be of order (0.5-1)" in size. Obtaining several resolution elements across the disk will allow us to determine whether the CO velocity field in the disk is different from Keplerian (as is hinted at in the first moment map shown in Figure 1).
We also request ACA observations for our targets to determine whether they have corresponding molecular outflows, with typical sizes of ~5-15" (e.g. Arce & Sargent 2006).

Source selection: Haro 6-37 is a binary system with a projected separation of 2.62" and a mass ratio of 0.90 (Harris et al. 2012), similar to the projected separation (1.3") and mass ratio (~0.6) for AS 205. The large difference in flux between the primary and secondary disks in this system (Harris et al.) also suggests that there is significant gravitational interaction between the two.
The remainder of our technical justification text is the same for all targets.
Spectral settings: We choose 12CO 2-1 at 230 GHz as our primary line target, with the goal of detecting any low-density extended emission. We additionally request 13CO and C18O, as these denser gas tracers can be used to study and model the velocity field of the protoplanetary disk if the 12CO emission has a significant non-disk component. We choose a high spectral resolution (0.08 km s-1) to fully resolve the velocity structure of the CO emission lines (expected to have widths of order 2-5 km/s), to match our Cycle 0 data, and because the line central velocities are well-constrained (to within ~5 km/s, compared to the 152 km/s bandwidth). The combined information gleaned from the three isotopologues and continuum is extremely useful for determining the mass and velocity of any extended structure and the underlying disk. Therefore, we believe that the high data rate required by this setup is justified.
Sensitivity: Our goals are to detect any extended 12CO emission, and to be able to characterize the velocity field of this emission if it exists. The second goal also requires high sensitivity observations of 13CO, as this is used to trace the disk velocity field. The observed extended emission around AS 205 N has peak fluxes near 0.5 Jy/beam, and so we require at least a nominal sensitivity of 0.05 Jy/beam to obtain a SNR per channel of 10 on any extended emission. Because we also want to study 13CO, we request a slightly higher sensitivity for FX Tau, which has a factor of ~10 less continuum flux than AS 205 N, suggesting it will also have significantly lower CO flux. We therefore request a sensitivity of 0.02 Jy /beam for FX Tau.
Spatial resolution: The high spatial resolution (~0.6") of the Cycle 0 extended configuration was crucial for resolving the sub-arcsecond structures observed around AS 205 N. For these observations, we request a slightly higher resolution (0.3") in order to obtain a few resolution elements across the protoplanetary disks, expected to be of order (0.5-1)" in size. Obtaining several resolution elements across the disk will allow us to determine whether the CO velocity field in the disk is different from Keplerian (as is hinted at in the first moment map shown in Figure 1).
We also request ACA observations for our targets to determine whether they have corresponding molecular outflows, with typical sizes of ~5-15" (e.g. Arce & Sargent 2006).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose here to follow up on our exciting Cycle 0 detection of extended CO emission from AS 205 N - a disk with IR spectroscopic evidence for a molecular disk wind. We will determine whether the extended CO emission is associated with one of two physical explanations. In the first, the extended CO emission is evidence for a disk wind, in which case we expect it to be associated with the IR signatures of disk winds, and potentially with larger-scale molecular outflows. In the second, the extended CO emission is unrelated to the IR wind signatures, and is instead due to tidal interaction with a companion. To distinguish between these scenarios, we will observe 4 targets - 2 with IR spectroscopic evidence for a disk wind, but no nearby companion, and 2 with no spectroscopic evidence for a disk wind, but with interacting close companions. With these observations, we will learn whether future searches for mm counterparts to the IR-identified disk winds are likely to be fruitful, and allow us to study disk winds and the transitions disks undergo as their outflows and envelopes diminish. Alternatively, we will learn how binary interactions affect protoplanetary disk structure.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals:
2011.0.00531.S "Discovery and characterization of disk winds from a newly discovered class of protoplanetary disks". Data in hand, and paper in prep.
2012.1.00555.S "What are the nature and impact of molecular disk winds?" No time granted.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
